Slides found with photographic prints: Lowell Thomas (Antarctica - from Cape Town to McMurdo Station, 1963): slide 1: Rear Admiral James R. Reedy and Lowell Thomas prepare to board one of the LC-130s of VX-6, Air Development Squadron, for the non-stop flight from Cape Town, South Africa to McMurdo Station, Antarctica; slide 2: Crews of both LC-130s shortly before departure on historic flight (non-stop) from Cape Town, South Africa to McMurdo Station, Antarctica. Left to right: front row - Lieutenant Commander Richard G. Dickerson, plane commander of lead plane, Rear Admiral James R. Reedy, Commander Task Force Forty Three, Commander George R. Kelly, Commanding Officer Air Development Squadron (VX-6), and Lieutenant Commander William B. Kurlak, plane commander of second plane; slide 3: Rear Admiral James R. Reedy, Lowell Thomas and pilots of VX-6 discuss plans for the non-stop flight by two LC-130s from Cape Town to McMurdo Station, Antarctica. Left to right: Lieutenant Commander Richard G. Dickerson, Lowell Thomas, Rear Admiral James R. Reedy, Commander Task Force 43, Lieutenant Commander Donald E. Miller and Commander George R. Kelly, Commanding Officer of Air Development VX-6; slide 4: The two LC-130s of VX-6, Air Development Squadron, ready to taxi out for take-off for the non-stop flight from Cape Town to McMurdo Station, Antarctica; slide 5: LC-130 aircraft #148320 of Air Development Squadron VX-6 at Naval Air Station, Rota, Spain where two of the squadron planes stopped for a crew rest during the flight to McMurdo Station; slide 6: LC-130 #148318 sits at the end of the running in preparation for take-off on the non-stop flight from Cape Town to McMurdo Station, Antarctica; slide 7: Rear Admiral James R. Reedy and Lowell Thomas
